full_text: Some of the key measures in #budget2018 include:
The significant increase in the budget for education over the last two years highlights the priority government has placed on education #budget2018
Where every person and every family has the opportunity to fulfil their potential #budget2018
This new investment will progress us towards our goal to make the Irish Education & Training Service #bestinEurope within a decade
This is the second consecutive year of major reinvestment in education in Ireland #budget18
Increase of €554m marks the largest ever education budget, at a total of over €10billion in 2018, a 5.8% increase #budget18

97% of 15-19 year olds are enrolled in second level education, well above the OECD average
18% of new entrants to tertiary education in 2015 chose STEM subjects, above the OECD average of 11%. Emphasising an uptake in STEM courses

The government today decided to increase Special Needs Assistants by 975, a 7.5% increase. Commitment to help all children achieve potential
Special needs assistants have continued to play a key role in helping children to participate and progress.
In 2017 my Department will invest €1.68 billion in special educational needs, almost one fifth of the Department’s entire budget.
975 extra SNAs brings the total number of SNAs to nearly 14,000 – the highest ever number
Today I announced an additional 975 Special Needs Assistants, a 7.5% increase, in order to meet the level of assessed demand.

@Murphynikkijune @Independent_ie hi Nikki, no that is not part of my proposal
@PaulaKearns3 @Independent_ie thanks Paula, yes all minority religions would receive the same protections under my proposal
@HanrahanAndy @cslireland @Independent_ie Hi Andy, SNA allocations will be released very shortly. Richard
There is no "silver bullet" solution here, it is my job as min for education to ensure the rights of all are protected in best possible way
Under my proposal, min religion schools are able to protect ethos, catholics can educate thru faith & non religious can access local school
My article sets out why we must carefully balance rights of catholic, those of min religions e.g. church of Ireland & non religious parents
I have an op-ed in the @Independent_ie today on the role of religion in school admissions & the importance of balance on this complex issue https://t.co/bVHDCbexdk
Admission to Schools Bill has just passed Dàil committee stage. Thanks to Oireachtas Education Committee and to all officials
I have come to this decision after extensive consultation on the issue – Oireachtas hearings, over 1,000 written submission & half day forum
I am just setting out my proposed approach at this point, clearly complex legal & constitutional issues are to be worked through
My preference is to remove use religion as criteria in admissions except in only a very small number of schools, of minority religion
I don’t believe parents, who might otherwise not do so, should feel pressure to baptize their children to gain admission to local school
I believe that it is unfair that children of a certain religion who might live some distance away are given preference over local children
This is a very important, complex issue & I believe my preferred option manages to strike a balance btw fairness & protecting min religions
I have set out my preferred option for addressing the role of religion in school admissions this evening
For the first time, we will be explicitly banning discrimination in school admissions
All schools will be required to consult with and inform parents where changes are being made to admissions policies
